title: Usage of proc_macro library for programming compilers that are not procedural macros
body:
The Rust error messages library (`Diagnostic` and the like) could be very convenient and useful to developers of compiler's prototypes. Unfortunately, `proc_macro` keeps private a bunch of functions that would be necessary to use it outside of the context of a macro. It is as simple as creating a `Span`, but also more complex as keeping track and managing source files.

Compiler developers have only few alternatives:

* Relying on library such as `syntex` that makes these modules and functions public (but it is not maintained anymore...).
* Build an in-house error reporting system (what a waste of time).
* Design the language as an EDSL in Rust to be able to use `proc_macro` (what if the host language is not Rust).

A solution might be to provide factory functions guarded behind an option, so the user needs to opt-in, as it would clearly not be the mainstream usage.

Long-term arguments in favor to make more `proc_macro` functions public:
* A first step towards a real toolbox for compiler programmers who wants to use Rust for prototyping. This is extremely common in research for example. Besides, researchers who would use Rust could also teach it.
* Obtaining a first-rate compiler with good error messages without spending too much time on the infrastructure.

Examples: two of my projects [bonsai](https://github.com/ptal/bonsai) and [oak](https://github.com/ptal/oak) rely on `syntex` for error reporting, and thus cannot be compiled on Rust stable.
